Award.AwardTitle: Diagnostics and Experimental Design in Nonlinear Dynamics
Award.AbstractNarration:
This grant is focused on developing statistical methodology for the parameters of ordinary differential equations and non-linear stochastic models that describe the evolution of physical and biological systems. The proposed methodological development can be broadly divided into two parts: (i) inferential methods and (ii)design of experiments. In inferential methodology, the investigator proposes diagnostic tests to assess mis-specification of the drift processes and the presence of state variables that have not been included in a proposed differential equation model. For the design of experiments, control-theoretic methods are suggested for experimental dynamical systems. Specifically, methods to choose system inputs so as to maximize the Fisher Information concerning the parameters of interest for the observed system are described. While models for rapid evolution in experimental ecologies provide real-world a real-world application, the proposed methods have much wider applicability, for example in chemical engineering, pharmacokinetics and neurodynamics.

The research in this grant will provide new, improved methods for making statistical inferences about real-world systems that change over time. As a specific example, we consider models that describe an experimental ecology in which different species of micro-organisms are grown together in a laboratory tank. However, this research has broader applications in areas as diverse as human immune systems, models for drug absorbtion by the body and chemical engineering. (I) A first task is to answer the question "Is the proposed model adequate to describe the data observed from this system and, if not, how should it be improved?" A particular question in experimental ecology is whether the models are missingspecies that are present in the system and which must therefore have evolved during the experiment. This research will provide the first statistical test of recently-advanced theories that evolution can occur at the same time-scales as ecological processes; theories that have profound implications for environmental protection, the management of algal ponds producing biofuels and many other domains. (II) A second focus of this work is to develop tools to improve the design of these experiments so as to obtain maximal information about the system from the data they generate. In ecological experiments, system inputs such as nutrients can be manipulated over time so as to produce the behavior that is most informative about the system's dynamics. Similar experimental design problems exist in neural dynamics, chemical engineering and pharmacokinetics. This grant will support the development of novel mathematical, statistical, and computational methods for addressing these issues.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Models of how systems change over time have long been a mainstay ofapplied mathematics and the physical sciences. They are often basedon general principles such as Newton's laws or a physicaldescription of a system.

A motivating example in this project comes from laboratory-basedexperiments in ecology undertaken at Cornell: algae and microsopicanimals called rotifers are grown together in a small (about1-quart) tank. The algae are supplied with nutrients which theyconsume and reproduce. In turn, rotifers consume algae andthemselves reproduce. This results in a system that producesboom-bust cycles as the rotifers exhaust the supply of algae andthen die off, allowing the algae to re-grow. This system is theinspiration for a series of classical differential equation modelsthat produce boom-bust cycles.

While this example serves as useful motivation for the developmentof statistical tools, the application of these tools is muchbroader Differential equation models are used to describe physicalsystems used in mechanical and chemical engineering, the spread ofdisease in populations, immune responses to disease, the absorbtionof pharmacuticals by the body, electrical signalling of neuronsalong with a host of other applications.
Despite their popularity in applied mathematics, there has beenlimited statistical methodology to fit these models to data. Thisproject built upon recent work on estimating parameter values forthese systems to look at larger statistical problems. This had twoparts: the first part developed methods to assess whether themathematical model fit the observed data it was meant to explain,and to produce tools to allow a model to be improved so as to fitbetter. The second was concerned with designing experiments: oftensome part of a system can be manipulated by a scientist and theproject asked if we can choose these as the experiment progresses,so that the observations yield as precise information about theunderlying model as possible.
In the motivating problem, the observed cycles differ from thoseproduced by mathematical models, particularly in the relativetiming of the cycles. Potential causes of this mismatch include: 1.random disturbances to the system that have not been accounted for,2. mis-specification of the details of the mathematical equations,3. components of the system that are missing from its mathematicaldescription. A hypothesized explanation for the mismatch was thatthe algae divide into two sub-species with differing ability toavoid predation, meaning a three-species ecology should be used.Our research developed methods to statistically distinguish thesethree possibilities. We found that while the second possibility wasstatistically supported, there was less evidence for the third.

In experimental design, on of the ways the system can be controlledis in the rate at which the algae were provided resources. Wedesigned ways to adaptively change the rate at which resources weregiven to the algae to allow improved estimates of the parameters inthe system.

The outcomes of the project include 

- training 3 PhD students who have since gone onto careers in  both industry and academia. 

- more than 20 academic papers detailing methods, theory and  applications.  - a book on statistical methods for differential equations models  was published in 2017. 

- development of a course on these methods intended for graduate  students in statistics and mathematics. 

- two workshops were organized at the Banff International  Research Station

The outreach portion of the grant was focussed on making thesemethods available to researchers in application areas. Inparticular:   

- The workshops both included a significant representation of    researchers from ecology, epidemiology, molecular biology and    chemical engineering.   

- The grant funded the development of the CollocInfer package    in the R statistical language, facilitating the application of    these methods for real-world results.   

- The book, "Dynamic Data Analysis", is focussed both on    statistics students, but intended to be accessible to applied    researchers as well.

The grant has sparked continuing research problems in designing thetiming of observations, in accounting for random shocks to thesystem, in extensions to high dimensional systems such as genesignalling and including models of spatial as well as temporalevolution of observed systems.
